text: Error: Error on client login: rpc error: code = 2 desc = "grpc: the client connection is closing"
did you start membership services?

that cmd :
make membersrvc && membersrvc
???
<@U1QSAT4T1>: yes
yes i did it

<@U1QSAT4T1>: I can think of of only this. If you had run this setup before, deleting the production folder might resolve this error. It is given at the end of the document(the link which you have shared). You have to stop the peer, membersrvc, delete the folder and can start them again.

OK thx I try that
I let u know if that works
Ask for help: I have to increase a counter (pay-per-query) in the Query function in chaincode. But I can't do it as Query function call is not a transaction.  What should I do?
At lease, I can Invoke the chaincode to increase the counter, then Query the chaincode.
But it will be quite slow.
you could also just build an application that handles the payment outside of the chaincode
and proxies to the chaincode if enough funds are available
<@U1QUCDJ8N|ericsomdahl> has joined the channel
<@U1R3610FM|alexrosen> has joined the channel
Is this "read the docs" for fabric new?

Hello, a little problem here. I'm starting up the project. Already got the vagrant up, and I'm ssh'ing into it... 

I'm following the docs in here <http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev-setup/devnet-setup/>
it says to use `docker images` and `docker rmi` to remove any old images (except for busybox or hyperledger/fabric-baseimage)
So i removed "peer-image"
Now I want to build it by doin `make peer-image`
(at `$GOPATH/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric`)
the shell responds with `make: Nothing to be done for 'peer-image'.`
:confused:
Is there some error in the docs?
I made `git pull` (I'm at `master`),  git says I'm up-to-date...

<@U1ENXTQRL>: take a look at the ci repo or Jenkins <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/gitweb?p=ci-management.git;a=tree> <https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/view/fabric/job/fabric-github-verify-x86_64/> take a look at the console log of a successful build
thanks <@U0UHG4VP1> !
Anyway, I wanted to shutdown (in order to re-start the vagrant VM)... I dunno why on earth I thought that `vagrant destroy` would be the right command.. :astonished:
setting it up again... :upside_down_face:
it’s easier the more you do it :slightly_smiling_face:
I bet. :smiley:

By the way, by "taking a look at the console log of a successful build", you mean this?

<https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/view/fabric/job/fabric-github-verify-x86_64/lastCompletedBuild/console>
sure, click the “full console log” thing for verbose spew
What should I be looking for exactly?
those show how we spin up and build fabric. I was hoping there was something in there along the lines of what you’re doing
build and test
Oh I see
that's useful
thanks
if you can replicate that, you can’t be far from what you want
Cool! :+1::skin-tone-3:

Hi, hoping yall can help me out with a problem I'm having. I have a Chaincode, where I'm routing all of my chaincode calls through Query because that seems to be the only where I can customize the data that gets returned. I basically use the Query as a handler, which then routes the transaction to another function. 

Now the problem Im having is that checking the peer logs, it gives me a QUERY_ERROR "(Cannot put
 state in query context). Notify"

Why am I not allowed to do a PUT_STATE just because my initial call to the chaincode was a query? So am I stuck with having to use invokes, but not being able to return my own JSON string in the message field like I can with query?

With an invoke, I only get a status OK that the chaincode received my transaction, but this is prior to execution. If I run into an error, it won't return the error in a REST response. With a query, the execution is done first, so if an error is encountered during execution, a REST response containing the error is returned to the client.
